Fields.DialogueText: Oi, you there!
Captain?
What are you doing in that hall locker and why is that rack of life vests such a mess?
Um, sorry? The ship pitched unexpectedly. The door wasn't quite shut and I stumbled into them.
Well, get them cleaned up.
Working on it...
No, no, so much wasted breath, so little attention! Sailor, first, your attitude! When you address your capitano, straighten up and smarten up!
Um... Marm!
Second, take some initiative! Look for the cause of problems and fix them. Do you see the latch on that door?
... Oh! It's broken. Should I get maintenance to fix it then?
Do so when you have gotten the vests back on their rack.
Yes, Marm!

Fields.MenuText: Wasn't that a bit harsh?
Which one of us is the captain here?
Wow... that was impressive.

Fields.DialogueText: That was only firm. Harsh would be if I threatened punishment for his misstep.
Pardon... you are, but I could not resist stepping in.
That was basic. Communication on a naval ship must be concise and problems must not be left to fester.
I see potential in you, Capitano, but you have a great deal yet to learn about command.
Apparently.
Though your steadfastness in battle has not been found lacking, which is fortunate because some Morganas have appeared to our east.
Duty calls, then.
@BATTLE
Sigh. Such dull and brutish work, however necessary.
Cavour? May I ask you something?
You're right. There's always more to learn about command, and I can't think of anyone better to learn from than you.
Really? You are asking me to teach you? Why?

Fields.MenuText: Self defense. I feel it's going to be hard to stand up to you otherwise.
I'd like to improve myself so I can better serve our ship and our cause.
Because you impress me greatly. Your example is one I'd like to live up to.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm. You're right, it would not do to seem the lesser member of our partnership.
Hm. Very individualistic, but noble in intent.
Hm. Quite flattering, but don't think I will go any easier on you for it.
Here. Start with this.
The Prince? Machiavelli?
That copy is a rare edition gifted to me by an associate working for the League. Please guard it against abuse or loss.
Isn't Machiavelli known to be rather... cruel?
A common misconception and a throughly modern one. Machiavelli was foremost an observer of the political realities of his time.
There is reason to believe, especially if you read his other work, that his true sympathies lay along republican lines. But those works will have less bearing on the command of a ship.
It is also worth remembering that his writing is itself something of a political accommodation. His patrons were the Medici family, the Renaissance lords of Florence.
Though fallen considerably in ability since the passing of Lorenzo the Magnificent, they still had the power to make his life quite comfortable... or quite miserable.
Anyhow, begin reading it as time permits you. I will periodically meet with you to discuss its points.
@BATTLE
Capitano. How is your reading coming?
Um, I think I'm through about the first quarter.
Capitano, remember what I said to that sailor? Concise, confident responses. Even if you are intimidated, project confidence. It will do wonders for others' sense of your presence.
Oh. I'm through the first quarter of the book.
Very well. This seems like a fine time for our first discussion.
Machiavelli discusses the two classes of principalities; that is, territories governed by a single ruler who is, generically, the "prince" of the title.
Which of the situations described is most like your position on this ship?

Fields.MenuText: An inherited principality, because the ship and its crew were here before you or I.
A new principality, because you chose me as your captain and I displaced the old one.

Fields.DialogueText: Wrong. If you had come up the usual way through the ranks of the Regia Marina that would be the case, but it is not.
Correct. The awakening of the Belles greatly disrupted the Navy's usual order.
The prince, or capitano, of a newly acquired territory must take steps to consolidate their gain and deal with the powers they are displacing.
Inevitably, this results in harm to some of those displaced, even if the usurper has noble intentions.
But I don't think I've hurt anyone...
My former capitano was quite livid at being usurped, you may remember.
Oh, right... I forgot about him. You didn't do anything drastic to him, did you?
Fortunately there are better options than murder. I saw to it that he got reassigned to a nice desk job. In Libya.
He was a blowhard, more bluster than brains. I was glad to see him go.
Of course not all Belles pass over their Navy-assigned capitani and not all displaced capitani are so troublesome.
A number of displaced capitani did assent to continuing on their old ships. You will find them as commanding officers on paper though they retain a degree of veto power they would otherwise lack.
Could my first officer override an order of mine? I didn't realize.
It is possible. It is more likely to pass the ensuing inquiry if you did something truly stupid.
However, I have had words with Officer Nicola and made it abundantly clear where my loyalties lie.
You may rely on him. He is a stalwart man with experience and a sound head.
Thank you, Cavour... I think.
And that is all the lesson for today. I sense battle approaching.
@BATTLE
Form up, recruits!
Whoever you are, whatever you were before you came here, you are now a member of what may be the most important military force in the world.
On land, maybe you were allies, maybe you were enemies. On this ship you are only brothers, and sisters, in arms.
If only it were as easy as a stirring speech...

Fields.MenuText: I've noticed. It's a miracle the INPF works at all.
As hard as it is, we've made progress.
It's a wonderful dream though- many nations working for a common goal.

Fields.DialogueText: And yet it does, most of the time.
True. But I find the INPF's open recruiting policy to be a constant source of fresh headaches.
And what will happen to that dream if – no, when – the Morgana threat is vanquished?
It's difficult and curious to think what Machiavelli would say about this motley band.
Enlisting foreign armies and mercenaries is a dangerous proposition for a ruler. They will always be beholden to other masters.
I suppose some recruits come with a mercenary mindset, but a lot of people are looking to get away from the war on land.
Justly observed. Machiavelli did not necessarily exhaust all the layers when it comes to what a person will fight for. The Fleet cannot conscript, so it must rely on volunteers.
If they join for money or to escape hardship, their loyalty may waver when the fight gets rough. But one who joins believing in the cause will do all they can to further it.
Nonetheless, international politics do not die on this deck. They must be watched closely; curtailed, if they are likely to cause harm...
And exploited if they can be used to your benefit?
You are catching on. Excuse me a moment.
Lieutenant? I am going to have to cut the orientation short. I sense enemy ships about two hours out. Show the recruits to their duty stations and their training partners.
Well, this will be one heck of an induction...
@BATTLE
Cavour? I'm struggling a bit with this section.
Hm? Ah... the character of a prince.
It is certainly one of the more contentious sections. Morals are a very personal thing.
Certainly there have been fine leaders who were resolute in their personal principles.
And you'll note that Machiavelli repeatedly warns against excessive depravity. A hated prince is liable to become an ex-prince.
Still, it is better to be feared than loved?
If one cannot be both. And each person may hold fear or love for a leader in varying quantities.
Would you say that criminals should not fear the law?
And on the other hand, is it not more noble for a citizen to uphold the law because they are convinced of its rightness?
Still, on the whole, you will find people are generally prone to folly.
Sometimes they can be led by appeal to noble desires, but more often they are driven by their baser needs.

Fields.MenuText: That's a rather pessimistic view.
I can see where you're coming from.
Honestly, the stupidity of people frustrates me sometimes.

Fields.DialogueText: I prefer "realist." Exceptions exist. They tend to be rare.
You'll see it all over human history. Those who break the mold are usually exceptional.
Ah, then you understand at least a little. You must be careful not to let on that you think it.
Personally, I will adjust my response to the situation. For example, allies are important.
But if remaining with an ally has become untenable, it is time to cut ties with them.
And I would not give someone mercy, generosity, or trust that they have not earned in some way.
And now we must respond to our own situation. I feel a Morgana attack is imminent.
@BATTLE
Cavour?
Hmm?
All this talk of politics never said much about current events. I'm curious...
You'll forgive me if I am more guarded in those opinions. There are too many people who might twist anything I say against me.
Maybe focus on the historical, then?
I'm not sure what I can say that isn't already obvious. Italy and Germany suffered from weak and ineffective leadership and their current leaders strong-armed their way into power.

Fields.MenuText: You approve of that?
I don't think I could ever condone that. Well... maybe if the old leaders were cruel.
You make it sound so matter of fact.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not inherently opposed to it. I care about what comes after.
A weak leader is prey to stronger ones. Nothing more, nothing less.
Because it is. Humankind is very predictable.
I don't mind saying that I distrust the Führer. He strikes me as rash. Unbalanced. He risks becoming hated.
And people seem to forget that he got most of his ideas about leadership from Il Duce.
What's your take on Mussolini then?
Shrewd. He certainly knows Machiavelli; he has published commentaries on the book. And he acts like he knows as well.
My opinion of him follows his performance. Even the Allied leaders were praising his strength before they suspected he had designs on expansionism.
Ultimately, Capitano, I want what is best for Italy. My namesake, Conte Camillio Benso, was instrumental in uniting the Italian nation. He was a hard man, but it is hard to doubt his effectiveness.
And I am not opposed to a war that is likely to increase Italy's power, provided we can win.
And now it's time we get back to the business of war. The Morganas we've been hunting are getting close.
@BATTLE
Capitano, I believe we have gotten all we can out of Machiavelli for the time being.
I encourage you to study further on your own, but for some things there is no substitute for practical experience.
All right. So what next?
The most important day-to-day skill when it comes to political maneuvering is the understanding and observation of people.
From that follows the fine art of social maneuvering and manipulation. How do you determine enemies from allies? How do you get the things you want?
So, we must know where we're starting from. Capitano, in dealing with other people, what sort of person do you consider yourself?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not that great with people. I try to hide it for the job.
I get along with people I guess.
You could call me a social butterfly.

Fields.DialogueText: You're on the right track. Controlling your reactions is a vital skill.
A fair start. But I bet you haven't given it much thought before.
That can be useful. But you must take care not to get too caught up in it.
In any interaction you must be aware of the manner you wish to project and envision it clearly. It will often depend on whom you're dealing with.
And we are about to be interrupted. How rude...
@BATTLE
Nice work last night, Cavour.
It's nothing. Capitano, I have thought of a test for you.
On a scale of "pop quiz" to "navy physical," how much trouble am I in?
It might actually be pleasant.
Capitano, we have known each other for a while now, but how much do feel you know me?

Fields.MenuText: Frankly, you are a woman of mystery to me.
I'm starting to get a handle on you, but there's a lot to learn.
I think I've got a pretty good sense of you.

Fields.DialogueText: Generally, that is how I prefer it. But we are partners.
A fair answer. I expect you'll have a good chance.
Do you? Well you will have a chance to prove it.
Your challenge will be to get me a gift.
... That's it? Is there a catch?
Not a catch, as such. But I will be very frank in my opinion of what you get me.
Imagine I am someone you are trying to impress, to win over to your cause. What sort of gift will best appeal to my temperament and character?
So the test is how well I judge you.
Correct. I will also add a few restrictions. One, you cannot simply ask me what to get. And I must ask you not to order me to tell you.
In fact, as much as I have enjoyed being able to have such frank discussions with you, you will find me throughly circumspect on this matter.
Two, it should not be extravagantly priced. Let's say your budget is one tenth of your monthly salary, give or take a bit.
Sounds fair. Can I ask other people?
I will not tell you what you can and cannot do, though I would advise against any tactic requiring physical violence.
I wasn't planning on it.
Unless it's Morganas.
I take it that's a subtle hint...
@BATTLE
Whew. So many Morganas in these waters. Drive one away and two more appear.
It's tiring, isn't it? Say, Signor Nicola, we've been so busy we haven't had much time for a proper chat. Join me for a drink later?
*Some Time Later*
...and I served aboard the Andrea Doria in the early '30s while she was undergoing her refit trials. Been with Cavour since '36.
Between us, I don't miss Capitano Bracci. Old money family with a chip on his shoulder... and I'm a scholarship boy from the naval college.
I bet you got along like fire and water. Cavour and I must be quite a change.
Ca...? Oh, the Countess.
You call her that?
A lot of us do. You don't think she might be listening in, do you?

Fields.MenuText: It's possible, but I can't imagine her caring.
I can't promise she isn't...but she won't cross me. You can speak freely.
She might, for all I know... maybe you don't want to say anything too outrageous.

Fields.DialogueText: She cares about a lot of things you wouldn't expect for reasons no one seems to know.
Well, I'll take your word on that.
I don't think I would offend her, but with her you never really know.
I guess I would call her... impressive, but also intimidating. What she gets up to is a mystery to most of us.
But she's very good at running things. Not afraid to go off the book if the situation calls for it and she's got a way of getting people to pay attention.
So she's pretty guarded around everybody, and you around her. That's not so helpful to me...
Pardon?
Oh, I'm trying to learn more about her and she considers it a challenge.
Can't say I can help you much there. I guess if you're brave you could try sneaking into her stateroom.
Probably not that brave. But hmm, I wonder...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Sailors, get ready to counterattack! Officers, get your squads ready! Move, now!
@BATTLE
(The lower decks are sure busy after battle. But this will attract less notice. Ah, there...)
Sailor Rocklin?
Captain? Is there a problem?
No, you're fine. But would you come to the bridge when you're off duty? I have a favor to ask...
*Some Time Later*
Come in, sit down. Can I get you anything special? A drink?
... A cigarette?
No problem. Here. There are matches in the caddy next to you.
Ahhh. Much appreciated. So, what do you want from me? Mostly I do grunt work for the upper ratings.
You're on the duty list for cleaning the officers quarters, which, we both know, entails a certain level of trust and discretion. That includes Cavour's.
I'm looking to get her a gift, but she makes it hard to find out what she might like.
Ah, so you want to know if I know anything. Hmm...
Well, she keeps it very shipshape. And would you know, she never fails to be in there when I am. "Please ignore me", she insists, but I swear she watches me over the top of her book.
What sort of book? More political theory, I guess...
Well, would you believe, I caught the title of one of them: Giardino Moderno.
Modern... Garden?
My Italian is shaky, but that sounds about right. Had flowers on the cover and all.

Fields.MenuText: It's hard to imagine... she's never been off the ship.
It's hard to imagine... she's actually someone interested in hobbies.
I guess I can't judge too hastily.

Fields.DialogueText: I guess that's why she'd read books on it?
I know what you mean. The Countess is always so serious about everything.
I guess. I gather the Belles are the same as people... complicated.
Hm, what else. There's some decorations. A crucifix... and she keeps a rosary on her dresser. A picture of Mussolini; she got very touchy when I asked about that.
Oh, and sunflowers. Poster prints I mean. You know, the famous paintings... Van Gogh, I think? She's got a couple of those.
I do think that will be helpful. Oh, here's the ash tray, and here, take the rest of the pack. And keep this discussion between us, would you?
Why thank you! Heh, this will make me popular in the bunk room for a while.
Capitano? There is an approaching Fleet ship, the Espero, looking to rendezvous with us. I don't recall a rendezvous on our itinerary.
Oh good, I've been waiting. I may have... neglected to mention it.
... I see. While I would otherwise applaud your success in arranging it without my knowledge, we now have a problem. See that to our west?
Damn Morganas!
It's unfortunate timing. I will have the radio officer relay the warning. Get ready.
@BATTLE
All right, the coast is clear. Conte, the Espero will be rafting some cargo over to us.
If this is about what I think it is, I wonder how you convinced them to play delivery service for you.
Thank Nicola for that. Turns out he's quite well-connected in the Fleet.
*Some Time Later*
Well Capitano, let's see how you did. This crate is quite heavy...
It's... a crate full of dirt.
Ah... it will make more sense when we have opened the other crate. Here.
Terracotta pots...
There should be a set of small tools in here and... ah, yes, good. Sunflower seeds, dwarf variety.
I thought about just getting some potted plants, but they would have been harder to transport and get here alive. And I thought you might like the chance to do it yourself.
The pots we can install around the bridge, particularly the navigation station. Maybe a few others on the railings if they won't get in the way.
... Hehe!

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you like it!
Cavour, I think that's the first time I've seen you smile like that.
Oh my. Did you just... giggle?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, yes, very much. Well done!
Oh? I mean... heh. I like this very much.
... You can't prove anything. But really, Capitano, well done.
I was hoping the budget I imposed might steer you down this path over some of my... pricier tastes. I would have been satisfied with potted flowers, but this shows ambition and creativity.
So how soon do you want it installed? I've roped one of our welders to come up with some mounting brackets so any time works for me.
Duty calls first. But I do believe I'm going to have a fun evening.
*ALARM*
All right, we can do this. There's not many of them. Prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
Whew. This is the second attack this week.
I've noticed. Have you picked up any chatter suggesting the Fleet is going to do anything about it?
Well...
Capitano.
Ah! Did you have to appear quite so suddenly and quite so close?
Pay attention. We are going to be hosting an INPF admiral.

Fields.MenuText: Exactly how long ago did you hear about this?
This is news to me.
And?

Fields.DialogueText: About two minutes. I have connections you do not.
I have information sources that are unavailable to you. It pays to be listening.
... I see you are less impressed than I was expecting.
Admiral Oliver Zenon is one of the Fleet's foremost strategists.
He is also very well connected. He is within the circle of admirals who can recommend fleet promotions and appointments to the League.
And you want information from him?
Yes. That will be your next test. And for the sake of verisimilitude, it will be a contest between the two of us.
... Is there a prize? Or some sort of wager?
Pride.
That's sufficient, isn't it? Excuse me.
The Countess, hmm?
So very imperious, yes. I wonder that you keep up with her at all.
He is one of a few who will be observing the capabilities of Belle ships and capitani as part of a larger effort to coordinate Fleet deployments.
Zenon, huh?
What's your take on him?
Well, he's French. If it's inside info you want, I'm afraid my connections are mostly in the Italian Navy.
As for public knowledge... old-money family with a lot of military history. Not just bluster either. They had renowned officers in a number of places through the Great War.
Oh, and he's fairly outspoken in support of the French republic, in spite of the Neutrality Fleet's efforts to downplay nationalist politics.
Capitano. There is a distress call from a supply cruiser in our area. You should come with me.
We must answer it, yes, but is it really necessary for me–?
No arguing. Come.
@BATTLE
I'm pretty sure she didn't have to interrupt us like that...
Maybe that was her plan? To present you as many obstacles as possible? Hinder your access to information?
Who can say? She surely won't.
Hmm. Capitano, Conte di Cavour can see all that goes on in and around her hull. When it comes to information you are at a distinct disadvantage. Do you really expect you can win?

Fields.MenuText: It's more about learning than winning.
Maybe not, but I don't think Cavour would let me back down easily.
I'd like to think I have a shot.

Fields.DialogueText: I guess that's reasonable. But mind what you are really learning.
You have a point. It's hard to say no to the Countess.
Do you? It would be interesting to see. She is a hard lady.
Well, it's not like anything important is on the line.
Oh? What is your pride worth to you then?
Capitano. The good news is we are nearly at the rendezvous and Admiral Zenon's transport has been sighted.
What's the bad news?
We've also sighted a pack of Morgana ships.
All right. Get on the radio with them. I trust you can best direct them to a safe position.
Of course.
@BATTLE
Bienvenue, Admiral.
Merci, madame. I dare say you are as impressive in person as you are in action.
And thank you too, Capitan. It must be challenging, coming to this task as you have. And la Maîtresse du Cavour's reputation precedes her.

Fields.MenuText: A good reputation, I hope.
I won't deny it's a challenge.
Is that so?

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, well, she is a... formidable lady.
Indeed. It's good to be honest about your strengths.
Indeed, but perhaps we should not worry too much about Fleet chatter.
Admiral, we must still oversee the cleanup from the fight, but I can have Officer Nicola show you to your quarters.
Ah, very well.
Your impressions, Capitano?
He's studied up on us a bit. I think I might be able to get with him "officer-to-officer" at some point. You?
I am keeping my thoughts to myself.
... Damn. I'm still thinking of you as a teacher.
Better adjust your thinking quickly then, mmm?
*ALARM*
*BOOM*
*ALARM*
Damnit, not now!
@BATTLE
Capitano, the fire on the deck is almost out.

Fields.MenuText: Fire? I didn't hear about any fire.
I heard, but thought it was small?

Fields.DialogueText: Then there has been an unfortunate lapse in communications. Fortunately, it was small.
Fortunately, it was. The men contained it quickly.
I must confess that in the chaos of battle I did not see how it started. If you would join me, an extra pair of eyes to survey the scene would be useful.
*Some Time Later*
Admiral. We've got things in hand up here, in case you were worried.
I trust you do, but I get restless if I'm too long below deck. And honestly, I feel a bit like a spare wheel. What's she...?
I cannot believe this. Not only do you leave grease rags near the flare locker...
I was working when the battle alarm sounded!
... You compound the offense by trying to hide the evidence after your stupidity has, quite literally, backfired on you!
It's a pity the Navy no longer permits caning as a punishment! If it were up to me...
That's quite enough, Maîtresse Cavour.
But Admiral...
Young man, is what she said true?
... Yes, Admiral.
Then you will have to be punished for lying to a superior. But it will be done by the book. You made a serious mistake, but it was a mistake. The important thing is not to make it again. Understood?
You there, Midshipman. Please escort him to the brig to cool his head for the night. I trust the other details will be dealt with later.
... Thank you, Admiral.
Admiral, I must protest. Fire on a ship is–
Cavour, you're not wrong to be angry. But he was terrified out of proportion to what the normal punishment would have merited.
"A prince ought not to mind the reproach of cruelty because with a few examples he will be more merciful than those who from mercy allow disorders to arise."
Yes, well, I can quote Machiavelli too. "The desires of free people are rarely pernicious to freedom...
...because they arise either from being oppressed or from suspicion they may be oppressed."
... Discourses on Livy.
You do know it then. Take it as advice. Fear is a blunt instrument. It has its uses, but it can bludgeon a man's better instincts as well as their baser ones.
I must return to my reports. Perhaps later we can debate political philosophy with more casual enjoyment.
I do believe he might be a match for you, Cavour.
I've arranged a workspace for you here on the navigation bridge, Admiral. Easier access to charts, brighter and cheerier than your quarters.
Splendid! But what's this? Pots mounted under the windows?
Sunflowers, Admiral. A few weeks of growth. I maintain them. It's hard to have gardening as a shipboard pastime, but it's a rather ingenious installation.
I brought the things in. But I'm quite happy to let Cavour maintain them, as is she.
Well I love the idea! Did you know my family owns a vineyard?
Of course, I–
Montagne-sur-Mer in Roussillon, yes?
Ah, you know it!
I am strictly moderate when it comes to drinking wine, but I make a point of being familiar with the esteemed names, especially around the Mediterranean.
Especially around Italy, I would think.
... I refuse to get dragged into a fight over whose wine is better. There might be bloodshed.
Hah! She's right there. We need a less partial judge. What do you think, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: French, of course. Though I'm more partial to Loire wines.
Er, French, of course. What else?
I know a trick question when I see one. No comment.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, fair! Roussillon's sweet wines are not for everyday tastes.
Hah, you flatter me. Even if I happen to agree with you.
Heh, very smart. We may have to resolve this with a taste test later.
I fear I must bring up the fact that we came up here so the Admiral could observe the upcoming Morgana fight... and I believe that fight to be now imminent.
Drat! I forgot my notebook. I will be right back.
Heh. Now you're playing in earnest, Capitano.
After the other day, I realize I might have a real chance.
We'll see about that.
@BATTLE
Nicola, have you seen Cavour? She's not answering my calls.
She's in the navigation station with the admiral. They've been working the charts up there for a couple hours now.
You mean she's been alone with him for two hours and they're working together? Damn. I guess their political opposition isn't as big an advantage as I hoped.
Can't fault their professionalism. It is the fate of the world at stake.

Fields.MenuText: True, we must put aside national differences against the Morgana threat.
I know the Morganas are the bigger threat, but I know I still struggle with my personal feelings.
Maybe, but we are fighting over the fate of the world on land too.

Fields.DialogueText: Hard as it is sometimes, I know.
Mm. Mostly I try to keep mine to myself. Much safer.
True. But if we lose at sea there may not be much world left to fight over.
*ALARM*
Yikes! No warning...
Very sudden... what's going on?
@BATTLE
Okay, what happened?
One minute, a clear horizon... the next, Morganas nearly inside our range.
I only had some seconds of warning. Of course, we've known that Morgana can literally appear out of nowhere, since that's how they arrived...
Which begs the question of why they don't simply do that all the time.
Perhaps it costs them a lot of energy. Or perhaps they have a limited range.
We can test the latter with statistical analysis. Though the stats I have will be incomplete.
You get your papers, I'll get the charts.
(They're practically finishing each other's sentences. I'm not going to get any words in edgewise here, am I?)
They're coming. Officers, prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
*YAWN* Mmmph.
Battle that boring, huh?
No. But I've been working long hours with the Admiral. Engaging as it is, I must retire and rest. I trust you'll handle things here.
Very well.
(Hmm. An opening...)
*Some Time Later*
I see you've found the officer's lounge.
Ah, Capitano. Yes, it's been a long day. I feel like I've earned some time for the privileges of rank.
I believe I can do you one better... I've got the keys to the liquor cabinet.
Fantastique! Now you're speaking my language. I don't suppose you stock Maury or Rivesaltes, so... brandy?
How about cognac?
Even better.
Hmm.
Something wrong?
Not really, except... no, perhaps I should not say.
(Hm. If I want to gain his trust... what would Cavour do?)
If you need a friendly ear, whatever you wish to say stays with me.
I am wondering how long it will be before we will get good cognac... or much else out of France again.
Capitano... what do you think of Cavour as a person? Be honest.

Fields.MenuText: She impresses me with her ability even if I can't agree with her views.
She is smart, strong, good at what she does... and very persuasive.
The more I learn of her views, the less enamored I am with her... but I still have to work with her.

Fields.DialogueText: I can understand that. She's one of the sharpest minds in the INPF, which is why I'm here.
Mm. Power and strength can be very seductive, Capitano. So we have seen in Italy...
Indeed. It's hard to say why a Belle picks the capitano she does, but there's no changing her mind. I would think less of you if you tried to dodge that responsibility.
I can do the job I'm here to do and I admit I could not do it half as well without her. But when I watch her in battle... it is hard not to think of Corfu.
Corfu?
Do you remember? The affair with the Greeks, the assassination of the Italian ambassador? When Greece would not grant Mussolini the terms of his ultimatum, he insisted a show of strength.
So in retaliation, Italy bombarded and invaded the Corfu island. Twenty civilians dead. The League was powerless to intervene. And Cavour fired the shells.
Granted, she was not here "in the spirit" as she is now, and she was under the command of other men. I cannot fault her personally.
But given her patriotism and taste for Machiavelli, I am not sure she would disapprove. For the sake of our working relationship I dare not press the issue.
And it is hard not to think that were it not for the Morganas, those guns could have been turned on Roussillon. Could still be if the Fleet fails.
If it weren't for the Morganas, Cavour probably wouldn't be here "in the spirit" as you say.
Perhaps.
Attention, crew! Morganas approaching! Everyone, get ready!
@BATTLE
Whew. That one shell was so close, I think my ears are still ringing.
I think I know a remedy for that.
More cognac? Yes, please.
*Some Time Later*
For all the INPF tries to present a united front, it's a mess. It needs steady hands and clear heads to keep everything in line.
You're on the committee for recommending appointments, yes?
(I'm getting warm! Got to be careful how I play this.)
Yes. It's quite a challenge. The top brass of the various nations are often too entrenched in their own countries' interests to be useful.
So we have to cast a wider net. Younger officers, or older ones that had retired before things got so politically tense, or experts from outside the military...
*KNOCK*
Capitano, Admiral. I heard drinks being poured and I thought a coffee with brandy would suit me after that battle.
... Of course.

Fields.MenuText: And I suppose the lure of interesting conversation doesn't hurt either.
I thought you'd be too tired to join us.
I suppose there's not much on the ship that escapes your notice.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course.
I have to be up a while longer anyway. Would have hated to miss this little gathering.
Not when it's in my interest, no.
Allow me, Cavour. If you don't mind me pouring something French in your cup, that is.
No, I'll allow that you probably have us beat when it comes to brandies... especially cognac.
(So close! Damn her...)
(I should really return Cavour's book. I'll just step into my room and grab it now.)
(... I swear it was in my bedside drawer. Did I leave it out and it slid off somewhere?)
(Craaaaaaaap... where is it?)
Capitano?
Yagh! Don't sneak up on me!
Is something wrong?

Fields.MenuText: Er... no?
I'm fine. Everything's fine.
Just trying to find something.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so.
If you say so. Well, everything for the moment.
I hear it helps to repeat the name of the thing to yourself while you search.
I came to tell you we are about to cross into the strait. Given the Morgana activity in the area and our current theories, we expect to be attacked promptly.
Thanks. I'll be there in a moment.
(Damn. This is Cavour we're talking about. How much does she know? How much trouble am I in?)
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Admiral. The reports you requested from Command have arrived in the latest dispatch.
Excellent. We'll be double-checking our theories against the engagement records. We're almost ready to make recommendations based on our analysis.
Sounds like a job well done.
Capitano. Admiral.
(Eek!)
Ah, Cavour. The reports are in.
Excellent. What do you say we start working through them after lunch?
Capitano, are you all right? You look a bit pale.

Fields.MenuText: Um, I'm fine! Perfectly fine!
Uh, I think something I ate is disagreeing with me.
Um, you startled me, is all.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you sure? Have you been getting enough sleep?
You should visit the infirmary. Illness spreading through a ship is a grave danger.
Oh? Are your nerves that rattled?
(Did she just smirk or am I imagining it?)
Capitano, maybe you should get some rest. Any military man quickly learns that–
*ALARM*
We've got a sudden incursion incoming! They really don't like us here.
(Well, my nerves are sure rattled now!)
@BATTLE
(Where is that godforsaken... Crap, that's the Morgana alarm.)
Seriously? No one's moved yet? Come the hell on, we're at war!
@BATTLE
And that's another job done. If you'll excuse me, I'll be in my quarters, reading.
(Sigh. I guess I'm going to have to face the music. Cavour might be able to find the book more easily than I can.)
Cavour?
Sorry to interrupt your reading, but...
... Wait. That's your copy of The Prince.
Mmhm.
The one I've been trying to find the last few days.
Oh?
I wanted to review something in here so I took the liberty of borrowing it back. I may have... "forgotten" to mention it.
... You knew.
It was worth it to put you off your stride. Given how much attention work needs, I was afraid you were speeding ahead of me.
You don't play fair.
Fair play is for chess players, Capitano. This is politics. Despite the frequent allusions they are nothing alike.
A political manipulator does not move the pieces... they orchestrate the people that do.
Hence my interest in cultivating Admiral Zenon as a connection. Technically, whether I win or lose this contest, I still gain.

Fields.MenuText: Do you want to know what Zenon really thinks of you?
You're a sly little devil, you know that?
You know, I should feel insulted, but it's hard not to admire your shrewdness.

Fields.DialogueText: I know it is unlikely we will ever be friends. I will probably still respect him whatever he thinks.
Heh. Sticks and stones, Capitano. I don't need to be loved... just respected.
You are not doing half bad yourself, to be honest. Given time and practice, who knows?
In any case, the game goes on. You know the Admiral will be leaving soon, right?
I am one step ahead of you.
Prudent. But the Admiral strikes me as one who cares more for personal touches than generic extravagance.
Nonetheless, we shall see what happens, hmm?
A fine dinner, Capitano. My compliments to your galley.
And Officer Nicola for arranging everything.
Indeed. Very steady head on his shoulders, excellent record, no extreme views...
You aren't thinking of taking him away from me, are you?
Ha! All I'll say is he fits the profile. There are many steps in between before things get serious and we do consider their current placement as well.
I'm curious... who–
So, Admiral. Your time here is almost up and we've hardly had any time to talk outside of work.
Ah, Cavour. I think we well have to forgo the verbal debate, but I hear you are quite the passionate letter writer?
Indeed. Perhaps you know I've been published in a number of Italian papers?
So close! She just keeps, butting in right when I'm making progress!
You know, maybe that's a sign she hasn't gotten far with him?
I wonder...
*ALARM*
Crap. So much for the party!
@BATTLE
All right Cavour, fess up.
Hmm?

Fields.MenuText: You haven't gotten anywhere with Zenon and that's why you keep barging in.
I would have won by now if you didn't have supernatural hearing.
You can't bear to think that you might lose, can you?

Fields.DialogueText: Do you have any other facts to support that? You know how much time I've had him to myself.
I told you, there's no fair play. You use every advantage you have.
No one is invincible, Capitano. It just pays to appear so.
But I am pleased you have warmed up to the game. I imagine us working together instead of against each other and I like what I see.
Cavour?
Hmm?
Are... are you trying to unnerve me by standing so close?
I am? ... Pardon.
(Was she just... blushing?)
Capitano, thank you so much for your accommodations. I believe now would be–
*ALARM*
Now would be time to deal with that. Good thinking, Admiral – no wonder you have that rank.
@BATTLE
The route to the harbor should now be clear, Admiral.
Excellent. So, before I leave, I have just one question...
Why do I get the feeling you two have been fighting over me like I'm a lady with one slot left on her dance card?
Um...

Fields.MenuText: Cavour has been teaching me to play politics and we were having a friendly competition. Admiral.
Sorry, we get a bit... competitive, in social circles.
Did you? Sorry. There's really nothing going on.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, is that all?
And Cavour's reputation for playing politics has nothing to do with it?
Come now... the innocent act does not suit you.
You know, I was expecting trouble from Cavour. One does not get placed as high up as I and not notice the train of displaced officials in Cavour's wake.
Though you surprise me, Capitano. I imagine you need some of it as a matter of self-defense.
Admiral... I sincerely apologize. I have been lax in the decorum owed to your rank.
Oh don't start kissing my ass now. I get enough of that from everybody else.
Lucky for you both, I am more amused than annoyed. May I suggest that next time you pick a target that doesn't have quite so much say in the future of your careers?
And with that, I must finish packing. Adieu, and I truly enjoyed working with you both. Do keep in touch.
I feel like this is a prime opportunity to impart the most important lesson of politics to you, Capitano. Don't get caught.
We're going to be assigned to harbor patrol for the next month, aren't we?
He will at least seriously think about it.
(Phew. Finally a quiet moment.)
*ALARM*
It's like the damn things hear me talking to myself!
@BATTLE
A fine afternoon, Capitano. A perfectly blue sky... once the wake of battle settles the sea, it will be quite striking.
Very poetic, coming from you.
The sea is in Italy's life-blood, and a bit in mine... figuratively speaking.
... We'll call it a draw.
All right.
So what did you think of the exercise?
I don't know if I'll ever be able to keep up with you, but it was educational.
There is much one can achieve with effort, as long as you have the temperament to apply yourself consistently and intelligently.
You have potential, Capitano. Unshaped, unrefined, but undoubtedly present. And I find that... attractive.

Fields.MenuText: You amaze me, Cavour. But you are a dangerous woman to know.
I'm not sure how I feel about that. There are sides of you I'm not comfortable with.
And do you mean to shape that potential yourself? What if I resist?

Fields.DialogueText: Good thing I'm on your side then, hmm?
If that's your opinion, so be it. It does not change my opinion of you, though.
That's up to you, Capitano. Will you be a pawn or a player? I will be pleasantly surprised if you turn out to be the latter.
Regardless of what you think, however, we have our duties first. I don't expect that to change. What I am sure of is that the alliance between us is one worth keeping.
That was... unexpected. But not bad. Maybe I should... No, that's silly. It's not like she's... God, I don't even know what's real anymore.
But then again, she isn't known for lying...
And I can't deny she's beautiful. Both as a woman and as a ship.
Listen to yourself, the things you come up with. I'd be sent to a madhouse. Wooing a ship.
It would be worth it, perhaps. God, am I seriously considering this?
Crap! I forgot she can hear me! I hope she didn't catch any of that.
Hope won't get you far in politics!
